moves.1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. d4 exd4 4. Nxd4 N:
Preventing Bd4.
Black's play is horrible, leaving the initiative to white
moves.16. Qf3 Bb7 17. Qe2 Qf6:
Using the Queen to block f4-f5-f6.
The biggest threat to black is an advanceof the f-pawn to f6.
moves.18. Rab1 Rab8 19. Bd2 Bc6 20. Qg4 Ne7: Still passive play, but blacks options are limited
moves.23... Bd7 24. Qg3 Nc6: Onto e5, black gains a foothold on e5 now
moves.27. Rxb8 Rxb8: Now black has gained an open b-line
moves.28. Rc1 Rb2 29. Bd1 Rxa2: I considered Bb5, to control c4, but freeing the a-pawn has a higher priority.
moves.30. Be1 Qg5:
Using the exposes rook, to force the exchnage of Queens.
Black realizes he has a superior endgame.
Black is in control of e5 and c4, and his Knight is stronger then whites Bissshop pair, which is obstructed by the  pwan structure. The free a pawn should win the game for black
moves.31. Qxg5 hxg5 32. Bd2 f6: Whites Bisshops are immobilzed by the pawn structure, but black Bisshop and Knight are still very active
moves.34. Rb1 c6 35. Kf2 Ra4 36. Be2 a6 37. Bx: Unexpected, and probably not a good idea
moves.37... cxb5 38. Kg3 Rxe4:
White surrendered.

After Ra1, Ra4, RxR, bxa4 black has a wining position.
The Bisshop canot stop the free a pawn without sacrificing more material.
